title-group.article-title: Tax Biases to Debt Finance: Assessing the Problem, Finding Solutions

abstract.p: Legal, administrative and economic considerations offer no compelling reason for the current tax advantage of debt finance in many countries. Instead, this 'debt bias' creates significant inequities, complexities and economic distortions. These are likely to be larger than previously thought, especially in the financial sector. To tackle debt bias, the most promising reform is to introduce an allowance for corporate equity, as some countries have successfully done. Its main obstacle is a budgetary cost, estimated at around 15 per cent of current revenue, on average for a selection of advanced economies. This cost can be reduced by granting the allowance only to new investment. The allowance could also be targeted to the financial sector and financed by special bank levies.

p.mixed-citation: See, for example, Slemrod (2009), Keen, Klemm and Perry (2010) and Hemmelgarn and Nicodème (2010).

Other aspects of the tax code matter too for the bias towards debt. For instance, non-debt tax shields, such as fiscal depreciation allowances and loss-offset rules, can reduce the value of the interest deduction as firms may run into taxable losses. Moreover, imputation systems (applied in Canada and Australia, for example) mitigate the double taxation of dividends by providing a credit in the PIT for the CIT already paid.

Incentives are especially strong in countries that exempt foreign dividends from domestic tax. They may be smaller under credit systems (applied in the US, for example) as the tax rate of the parent country then ultimately applies also to foreign income. However, credit systems generally allow deferral until repatriation and do not provide credits for taxes that exceed the home-country tax. This brings credit regimes closer to exemption and makes debt shifting important for credit countries too. Japan and the UK have recently moved from credit to exemption systems.
ZEW and Oxford University Centre for Business Taxation, 2008.

Existing studies have established these results only for CIT. The impact of PIT on corporate finance depends on who is the marginal investor (PIT-exempt or PIT-taxed), which has been difficult to identify. The impact of PIT is therefore largely an open empirical issue (Graham, 2008).

Broad leverage includes non-debt liabilities, such as accounts payable to creditors, reserves, insurance and non-interest-bearing liabilities. The difference from debt is large; see, for example, Rajan and Zingales (1995). For instance, the average debt-asset ratio is 0.26 while the average leverage-asset ratio is 0.57 in the studies reviewed.
Some caution is required here, since data and estimation techniques may have improved over time, leading to more precise and perhaps larger estimates.
In light of the non-linear increase in the probability of default in response to lower capitalisation, even small changes in leverage by large banks can have significant welfare losses.

According to Myers and Majluf (1984), debt is favoured over new equity as a source of external finance. The reason is that management will not issue new shares if the firm is undervalued, so issuance of new shares is a signal of overvaluation. This gives rise to adverse selection. It leads to the pecking order in corporate finance: (1) internal finance, (2) debt and (3) external equity.
For instance, empirical studies report significant positive effects of a firm's cash flow on investment (Hubbard, 1997), which is consistent with credit rationing of firms.
To the extent that debt bias creates larger welfare cost in the banking sector than in other sectors, this warrants attention for special banking taxes (Claessens, Keen and Pazarbasioglu, 2010).

Banks and Diamond (2010) offer a comprehensive analysis of the arguments for taxing the normal return on capital, concluding that a positive tax is likely desirable. After weighing the pros and cons of taxing the normal return, Mirrlees et al. (2011) in Tax by Design argue that a consumption-based tax system is preferable.
Institute for Fiscal Studies, 1991; Devereux and Freeman, 1991.
Mirrlees et al., 2011; Griffith, Hines and Sorensen, 2010.

This subtraction is necessary to avoid double tax relief. Indeed, an ACE frees the normal return on equity participations from tax. If the parent were granted an ACE on all equity, including that used to finance participations in related entities, it would receive an allowance for returns that are untaxed.

This rule for the ACE rate is derived under specific assumptions - for example, it would not apply in the presence of imperfect loss offset - but carries the advantage of simplicity as risks do not have to be differentiated across companies.

In present-value terms (not year by year), the revenue impact is equivalent to that of a cash-flow tax, which allows investment to be deducted immediately instead of depreciated. The Meade Report in 1978 discussed two versions of the cash-flow tax. The R-base would eliminate interest deductions and the taxation of interest income (as under CBIT), while the R+F-base would preserve these and add net borrowing to them. The main difference between the two is the treatment of banks (which would go untaxed under the former). In Tax by Design, Mirrlees et al. (2011) arrive at a preference for the ACE over a cash-flow tax, which would involve large transitional difficulties. In his commentary, however, Gordon (2011) seems not entirely convinced and points to the benefits of an expenditure tax system with a business cash-flow tax.

Recent papers take into account agency problems, created by the conflict of interest between managers and firm owners. This may alter the efficiency properties of the ACE. For instance, Koethenbuerger and Stimmelmayr (2009) argue that eliminating the tax on the normal return to investment stimulates not only productive investment, but also unproductive pet-projects that aggravate the conflict of interest between the shareholders and managers. Keuschnigg and Ribi (2009) emphasise the distortions of ACE and cash-flow tax systems when firms are credit constrained.

The ACC raises a question, however, about the tax treatment of interest income received, similar to the taxation of banks under CBIT. Indeed, taxes on banks may need to be modified to avoid double taxation of interest.
